sections.content: The following cases demonstrate how Promptotyping principles emerge from and adapt to real-world contexts. These aren't idealized success stories but honest accounts of what happened, including confusion, dead ends, and lessons learned through failure.
Case 1: Stefan Zweig Digital Annotation Tool

The Stefan Zweig case illustrates a fundamental principle: expert domain knowledge shapes successful LLM collaboration. The developer's familiarity with digital humanities needs enabled critical interventions that prevented the common trap of over-engineering. When Claude suggested AI-assisted features, collaborative editing, and advanced visualizations, the developer recognized these as unnecessary complications for a single researcher's tool.

Using Promptotyping to document Promptotyping created unique challenges and insights. The recursive nature of the task – applying a methodology to describe itself – revealed both strengths and weaknesses. The tendency toward abstraction became immediately apparent, as did the value of concrete examples over theoretical description.

Perhaps the most instructive case is the methodology's own evolution. The transformation from a 50-page academic paper to a practical guide demonstrates how community feedback and honest reflection can strip away unnecessary complexity to reveal core insights. This wasn't a failure of the original version but a natural refinement process – exactly what Promptotyping advocates.

Across all cases, certain patterns emerge consistently. Expert intervention prevents feature creep. Clear constraints lead to simpler solutions. Flexibility in phase application proves essential. These aren't rules but observations – patterns that practitioners might find useful when adapting the methodology to their own contexts.
